subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Quickscript for American English
msgSnippet: kyudosha: There are a number of dialectical differences between Received pronunciation (British English) and American English, just as there are dialectical
messageBody:
kyudosha:

There are a number of dialectical differences between Received
pronunciation (British English) and American English, just as there are
dialectical differences across America.

No. 30 is used for the initial vowel sound in "Andy."
No. 31 is used for what we called in school the "long i" sound.
No. 32 is similar to No. 34, but represents a longer vowel sound. Think
of a Brit dragging out the initial vowel as they say "father". If you
pronounce "father" like "bother," you probably don't need No. 32.
No. 34 is a shorter sound as in "hot" or "cot."
I use No. 33 for the vowel sound in "caught" or "awe" although there is
a vowel shift still underway in America which combines "caught" and
"cot" so that they sound the same. To those who still make the
distinction, it sound very peculiar to hear someone speaking who does
not make it.

Paige Gabhart

kyudosha wrote:

>I've noticed an interesting thing about the Read Alphabet (from an
>American perspective). Numbers 31 and 32 (and to an extent 34) are
>differentiated as separate sounds, yet are pronounced the same by
>American English speakers. While I understand that the unused
>letters can simply be omitted, there remain two questions:
>
>1) Which letter is the one to be used for this sound as an American
>writing in Quikscript?
>
>2) Can one of the unused letters be used to represent the (distinctly
>American?) vowel represented in the IPA alphabet as: "æ"? This
>sound
>would be used in such words as "Canada" and "Andy", not to mention
>the all-important "and". Has this already been suggested, and if so,
>what is the accepted standard for this?
>
>AJW
>
